channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: After U.S. Compromise, Security Council Strengthens North Korea Sanctions
item.media:description: Bridges over the Yalu River connecting North Korea and China. A new proposal by the United Nations Security Council sets a cap on oil exports to North Korea, but does not block them altogether.
item.description: The Security Council adopted a measure that sets a modest cap on oil imports to North Korea, far weaker than what the United States had sought.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Sub-Saharan African Migrants Face Old Enemy in Libya: Bigotry
item.media:description: Migrants at a detention center in Zawiyah, Libya, in June.
item.description: For many African migrants trying to reach Europe, the way station of Libya can carry special peril if their skin is darker, a new report says.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: South Korea Plans ‘Decapitation Unit’ to Try to Scare North’s Leaders
item.media:description: South Korean marines during a military exercise on Baengnyeong Island, near the disputed sea border with North Korea, last week.
item.description: The government is pouring money into strategies and weapons it hopes will act as a deterrent against Kim Jong-un, the nuclear-armed dictator across the border.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Far From Myanmar Violence, Rohingya in Pakistan Are Seething
item.media:description: Hoor Bahar, 60, lives in the Arkanabad slum in Karachi, one of the estimated 500,000 ethnic Rohingya in Pakistan from an exodus in the 1970s and ’80s.
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya from another exodus, stuck in impoverished Karachi slums, are distraught that their people aren’t receiving help anywhere.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: In the Caribbean, Rebuilding Nations — and the Tourism Industry
item.media:description: Cubans wading through a street in Havana after Hurricane Irma battered the city.
item.description: As a region assesses the damage wrought by Irma, officials say it could take years for tourism to fully recover.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Singapore Has a New President, No Election Needed
item.media:description: Halimah Yacob, the former speaker of Singapore’s Parliament, will become the country’s first female president on Wednesday when she is sworn in without a vote.
item.description: The public is questioning the legitimacy of a qualification process so narrow that only one candidate made the cut, bypassing a vote.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Protest in Catalonia Adds to Pressure Before Independence Vote
item.media:description: Hundreds of thousands of people celebrated the Catalan National Day on Monday in Barcelona.
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Catalans celebrated their national day in Barcelona, vowing to hold an Oct. 1 referendum on whether to break from Spain.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Ruling Conservative-Led Bloc Wins Norway’s National Elections
item.media:description: Prime Minister Erna Solberg of Norway casting her ballot on Monday at a polling station in Bergen.
item.media:credit: Marit Hommedal/NTB Scanpix, via Getty Images
item.description: A race that was close in opinion polls, the election was viewed as a referendum on taxes, immigration, energy policy and European integration.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Cambodia’s Opposition Chief Loses Immunity in Treason Case
item.media:description: A journalist recorded footage of a television screen as Cambodia’s Parliament voted to remove the parliamentary immunity of the country’s opposition leader, Kem Sokha.
item.description: Parliament has approved the prosecution of the opposition leader, Kem Sokha, stripping away his last shield in a crackdown by Prime Minister Hun Sen.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE

item.title: Europe Edition: Florida, Rohingya, North Korea: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER JETT

item.title: President of Guatemala Wins Vote to Preserve His Immunity
item.media:description: President Jimmy Morales during his annual State of the Nation address in Guatemala City in January.
item.description: The move by Guatemalan legislators means that President Jimmy Morales will not face scrutiny in a campaign finance investigation.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: As Mexico Earthquake Aid Mounts, Many Fear It Will Be Diverted
item.media:description: In Juchitán de Zaragoza, Mexico, people waited to receive supplies from Cadena, a relief group, on Monday.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: After several corruption scandals, Mexicans are reluctant to trust officials charged with providing food and reconstruction supplies to the victims.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Florida, Myanmar, Pope Francis: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Gary Lloyd Mccullough/Florida Times-Union, via Associated Press
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Sentencing of Tatar Leader in Crimea Is Called a Sham
item.media:description: A crowd outside the Crimean Supreme Court in Simferopol on Monday. The court sentenced a Tatar politician to eight years in prison on charges that he incited mass riots in 2014.
item.description: The leader, Akhtem Chiygoz, was found guilty of inciting mass riots protesting the Russian presence in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Macau Journal: A ‘Futurist Woman,’ a Defunct Casino, and a Fight for Macau’s Soul
item.media:description: The Hotel Estoril, built in 1962, marked a transition in Macau from opium-filled gambling dens to casino resorts aimed at a wider public.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The 1960s hotel, Macau’s first casino resort, is not an architectural treasure, but many residents, especially the young, have an emotional connection.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: She Was Teaching Him to Walk. He Shot Her From His Wheelchair.
item.media:description: Patients were evacuated from the Red Cross hospital in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, on Monday after a patient killed a Red Cross physiotherapist.
item.description: The Afghan polio patient, who had received 19 years of treatment from the International Red Cross, opened fire on his physiotherapist. She was killed.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Rohingya, Irma, North Korea: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Justice Kennedy’s Order Temporarily Leaves in Place Trump Travel Ban on Refugees
item.media:description: Protesters at a rally against the separation of families under President Trump’s travel ban in New York in June.
item.description: Justice Kennedy issued an administrative stay in the travel ban case, temporarily blocking an appeals court ruling on refugees.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK

item.title: Pope Criticizes Climate Change Deniers and Trump on DACA
item.media:description: Pope Francis talking to journalists on Monday while flying to Rome at the end of a five-day visit to Colombia.
item.description: On his flight back to Rome, Pope Francis said climate change deniers need to consult scientists and urged President Trump not to end DACA.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Decades After Alcohol Ban, Iran Admits It Has a Problem
item.media:description: Nasser, a taxi driver who has been sober for three years, serving tea at an Alcoholics Anonymous association meeting last month in Tehran.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: Drinking remains a crime, but Alcoholics Anonymous is flourishing and dozens of private and government clinics have opened alcohol rehabilitation centers.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Merkel Suggests Germany Should Join North Korea Talks
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at a Christian Democratic Union party meeting on Saturday. She is seeking a fourth term in the Sept. 24 elections.
item.media:credit: Christoph Schmidt/Deutsche Presse-Agentur, via Getty Images
item.description: With German elections approaching, the chancellor highlighted her global status by urging negotiations with North Korea based on the model of the nuclear deal with Iran.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: China’s Currency Rebounds as Economic Optimism Returns
item.media:description: Buildings under construction in the northeastern Chinese city of Qiqihar. China’s economy has been growing steadily despite mounting worries about debt and other problems.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Though the country faces long-term problems, like soaring debt, the government’s recent moves have reassured investors that it can stave off crises.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Rohingya Crisis in Myanmar Is ‘Ethnic Cleansing,’ U.N. Rights Chief Says
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees from Myanmar in late August, after crossing into Bangladesh. More than 300,000 have fled a military crackdown.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The security campaign that has led more than 300,000 people to flee to Bangladesh is in clear violation of international law, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Breakdown: Girls in Western Australia Gain Right to Wear Pants and Shorts to School
item.media:description: Students at a private school in Sydney. It is unclear how many schools across Australia require girls to wear skirts.
item.description: Public schools in Australia have often mandated that girls wear skirts, which can inhibit physical activity. Complaints about the policy have renewed momentum.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Europe Edition: Hurricane Irma, Apple, Pope Francis: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:credit: Paul Chiasson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN HILTNER

item.title: Need to Catch Up on the German Election? Here’s a Guide
item.media:description: Journalists watching a debate between Chancellor Angela Merkel of the Christian Democratic Union and her challenger, Martin Schulz of the Social Democratic Party, in Berlin.
item.description: With the vote on Sept. 24, read New York Times coverage to learn more about the election and the issues that have been roiling Germany and Europe.
item.dc:creator: MILLIE TRAN

item.title: Desperation Mounts in Caribbean Islands: ‘All the Food Is Gone’
item.media:description: A street in St. Martin after Hurricane Irma. Residents spoke of a disintegration in law and order as survivors struggled in the face of severe food and water shortages.
item.description: Food and water were in short supply on many islands in the Caribbean after Hurricane Irma, and witnesses spoke of a disintegration of law and order.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Pope Ends Colombia Visit With Plea for Those ‘Still Being Sold as Slaves’
item.media:description: Pope Francis visited the Sanctuary of St. Peter Claver, the patron saint of slaves, in Cartagena, Colombia, on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alessandro Di Meo
item.description: Rounding out a six-day trip, Pope Francis visited the bones of a Roman Catholic saint who devoted his life to helping slaves in the 17th century.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: ‘Uncontacted’ Amazon Tribe Members Reported Killed in Brazil
item.media:description: Members of an uncontacted tribe in Brazil in 2008. Indigenous groups in the Amazon are under increasing threat.
item.description: Investigators are looking into reports that around 10 tribe members died when they were set upon by gold miners.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: Ex-Leader, Now a Man Without a Country, Surfaces in Ukraine
item.media:description: Mikheil Saakashvili trying without success on Sunday to travel into Ukraine from Poland by train.
item.description: Mikheil Saakashvili, a former president of Georgia who is stripped of citizenship there and in Ukraine, is an exceptional position: He’s a stateless ex-head of state.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Hurricane Irma, Apple, Myanmar: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Guardia Sanframondi Journal: Religious Rite Takes Hamlet Back in Time Every Seven Years
item.media:description: Penitents known as “battenti” beating themselves with nails in Guardia Sanframondi, Italy, during a religious procession that takes place every seven years.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: An ancient Catholic procession featuring hooded faithful and parades attracts thousands of tourists to a village in Italy’s south.
item.dc:creator: Text by GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Nancy Hatch Dupree, Scholar of Afghanistan, Is Dead at 89
item.media:description: Nancy Hatch Dupree at the Afghanistan Center at Kabul University in 2014.
item.description: Mrs. Dupree, who arrived in Afghanistan in 1962, devoted decades to preserving the country’s heritage in its darkest days.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage

item.title: Mass Trial Over Turkey’s Coup Plot Becomes an Arena of Emotion
item.media:description: Soldiers accused of participating in the failed coup last year were escorted to a hearing in Ankara in August.
item.description: Nearly 500 servicemen and civilians are on trial, accused of planning last year’s bloody coup attempt, a proceeding that has stirred deep passions.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Mexico Mourns After Quake: ‘We Have No Idea How We Are Going to Rebuild’
item.media:description: Mourners on Sunday at the funeral of Juan Jiménez, a police officer in the Mexican city of Juchitán de Zaragoza, Oaxaca, who died in the earthquake.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: With the death toll of Mexico’s strongest earthquake in living memory reaching 90, and further aftershocks, rescue workers began to assess the damage.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Indonesia, Long on Sidelines, Starts to Confront China’s Territorial Claims
item.media:description: Security ship crew members of the Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries prepare for a patrol along Indonesia’s exclusive economic zone in the Natuna Islands.
item.description: A military buildup and maritime skirmishes involving Chinese boats suggest a more aggressive posture by Indonesia in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Egyptian Archaeologists Find Goldsmith’s 3,500-Year-Old Tomb
item.media:description: Egyptian antiquities workers with three ancient mummies discovered in the tomb of Amenemhat, a goldsmith, at the Draa Abul-Naga necropolis near the Nile city of Luxor.
item.description: It belonged to a royal goldsmith who had lived in the desert province of Luxor, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Instead of Launching a Missile, North Korea Throws a Party
item.media:description: An image from the North Korean state news agency purporting to show Kim Jong-un and his wife, Ri Sol-ju, to his right, at a performance on Saturday to celebrate North Korea’s nuclear test.
item.description: Kim Jong-un honored his nuclear scientists for their recent test explosion as the world waited for an intercontinental missile test seen as inevitable.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Pope Francis Shifts Power From Rome With ‘Hugely Important’ Liturgical Reform
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving to lead a Mass in Colombia on Saturday.
item.description: By giving more power to bishops to translate prayers into their local languages, Pope Francis reverses Vatican policy enacted by his more conservative predecessors.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Kabul Streets Turn Violent in Annual Reminder of Civil War
item.media:description: A portrait of Ahmad Shah Massoud, an anti-Taliban leader. His supporters turned out on the streets of Kabul on Saturday, the anniversary of his death in 2001.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Armed supporters of Ahmad Shah Massoud, an anti-Taliban leader killed in 2001, took to the capital’s streets on the anniversary of his death.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Malaysian Leader, Under Corruption Cloud, Will Meet With Trump
item.media:description: The United States Department of Justice has been investigating Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia for corruption for over a year.
item.description: The White House visit by Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is being investigated by the Justice Department in a case involving billions in missing funds, may give him a political lift at home.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Ex-Inmate Takes to Hong Kong’s Airwaves, and Prisoners Tune In
item.media:description: Bruce Aitken on the air during his Sunday evening radio show, “Hour of Love,” in Hong Kong. The show has gained a large following among foreign prison inmates in the city.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Bruce Aitken, a convicted money launderer, sees his radio outreach to prisoners and their families as his “own personal penance.”
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: As China Moves In, Serbia Reaps Benefits, With Strings Attached
item.media:description: Workers loading a roll of steel onto a barge in Smederevo, Serbia, in June. A state-owned Chinese company bought the steel plant in the Serbian city.
item.description: China’s leader promised the poor Balkan nation jobs, cash and investments, but its “One Belt, One Road” initiative is on a collision course with E.U. projects.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: Paraplegic Girl Attacked by Rats in France, Spurring an Investigation
item.description: Rats in northeast France repeatedly bit a disabled girl as she slept, according to her parents, who say they were upstairs at the time.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Death Toll Climbs, and Relief Efforts Stall, as Caribbean Braces for Hurricane Jose
item.media:description: French rescue teams heading to the island of St. Martin on Friday.
item.description: Aid workers responding to devastation from Hurricane Irma have been stalled by the next dangerous storm: Hurricane Jose.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Trump’s Bid to End Saudi-Qatar Stalemate Ends in Recriminations
item.media:description: The crown prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman, left, and the emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani. They spoke by phone on Friday.
item.description: President Trump brokered a phone call with the leaders of Qatar and Saudi Arabia that later resulted in dueling, ill-tempered statements.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Leveled Mexican Town Digs for Survivors. ‘Can You Tell Me if My Dad’s O.K.?’
item.media:description: Rescue workers searched for a police officer buried under the rubble of a collapsed building in Juchitán de Zaragoza, Mexico, after a powerful earthquake.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: Rescue workers in Juchitán de Zaragoza searched desperately in the ruins of town hall for the police officer who guarded the building at night.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: U.S. Students in Florence Accuse Police Officers of Rape
item.description: Italian authorities are investigating the accusations, and Italy’s defense minister has said there appeared to be “some basis” to the allegations.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ
